text: the incredible story of how the
hippopotamus almost became the staple of
the American style in the early 1900 the
United States began to experience the
meat shortage over grazing
overpopulation and a surging demand
abroad were the main causes at the same
time
southern Louisiana was being overtaken
by an invasive species water hyacinth
which or transporter there is a gift
from the Japanese delegation during the
1884 World's Fair the hyacinth
multiplies like rabbits entirely
covering swamps by rivers and other
water bodies making navigation by boat
almost impossible destroying shipping
around and greatly affecting local
ecological systems in less than 20 years
Louisiana was covered in water hyacinth
the army even tried pouring oil on them
and setting swamps on fire but the seeds
can survive for almost 30 years
Louisiana congressman Robert Broussard
gathered two partners adventurer and Boy
Scout founder Frederick Burnham and
Fritz Duquesne the big-game hunter who
spied for Germany during both world wars
the partners created the new food supply
Society with the goal of imported
hippopotamuses to Louisiana
they argue that hippos would eat all the
hyacinths that were covering the water
and wood provided significant source of
meat for the South amazingly the plan
had the full support of Teddy Roosevelt
in the US Department of Agriculture in
1910 Broussard introduced HR to 36 to 1
also known as the American hippo bill
the plan would have caused 250,000
dollars at the time about six million
dollars today it had the support of the
New York Times The Washington Post and
many other major papers the New York
Times even wrote how excited it was for
Lake Cal baking the bill failed by one
vote
and while Burnham and decane both tried
to continue the project the Mexican
Revolution and World War one would
eventually draw away their attention and
the plan was forgotten today the state
of Louisiana spent millions of dollars
regularly spraying herbicides to destroy
the water hyacinth
you
